title: Maroon 5 dedicates heartfelt new Memories music video to late manager Jordan Feldstein
text:
Maroon 5 dropped the music video for their new single Memories.

The band and its frontman, Adam Levine, dedicated the heartfelt and melancholy song to their late manager, Jordan Feldstein, who was the older brother of actors Jonah Hill and Beanie Feldstein.

Turns out Jordan, who passed away in December 2017 from a blood clot at the age of 40, was the inspiration for much of the lyrical content of the stripped down song.

Scroll down to video

Emotional: Maroon 5 dropped the music video to their new heartfelt single Memories

RIP: Jordan Feldstein passed away from a blood clot in December 2017 at the age of 40

Keeping with the stripped down theme, the video begins with an extreme close-up of Levine's face as he belts out the opening lines.

'Here's to the ones that we got / Cheers to the wish you were here, but you're not / 'Cause the drinks bring back all the memories / Of everything we've been through.'

At times Levine had to take some deep breaths to compose himself with other lines like, 'There's a time that I remember when I never felt so lost / When I felt all of the hatred was too powerful to stop / Now my heart feels like an ember and it's lighting up the dark / I'll carry these torches for ya that you know I'll never drop.'

Personal: Much of the lyrics to the song were inspired by their late manager, Jordan Feldstein, who was the older brother of actors Jonah Hill and Beanie Feldstein

Stripped down: The video began with a closeup of Levine's face and the lyrics: 'Here's to the ones that we got / Cheers to the wish you were here, but you're not / 'Cause the drinks bring back all the memories / Of everything we've been through'

The video pans out ever so slightly during the video to reveal Levine's shirtless shoulder and chest and many tattoos he has on the upper portion of his body.

The song also features such emotional lyrics as, 'Everybody hurts sometimes / Everybody hurts someday, aye aye / But everything goin' be alright / Go and raise a glass and say, aye.'

Once the last shot of Levine faded to black, the band dedicated the video to Feldstein by writing, 'For Jordi.'

Raw: At times Levine had to take some deep breaths to compose himself

Simple: The video pans out ever so slightly during the video to reveal Levine's shirtless shoulder and chest and many tattoos he has on the upper portion of his body

'First and foremost the song is for everybody,' the 40-year-old singer explained during an appearance on The Howard Stern Show on Tuesday

During an appearance on The Howard Stern Show on Tuesday, Levine revealed that that loss of his friend, and the lyrics behind the song, are 'still king of raw.'

'First and foremost the song is for everybody,' the 40-year-old singer explained to Stern.

'I wanted to make sure I could personalize it and have it be about our manager, who passed away very recently. And this is all still really raw, so it's hard for me to kind of elaborate on. [He was] like a brother.'

'I needed this song,' he continued. 'In a world that's increasingly chaotic and crazy and angry in a lot of ways, I feel like rather than fight about things, it's nice to have common ground and all of us have had loss. [It's about loss] and celebrating them too, which I think is important.'

Broad meaning: Levine said the song is about loss but at the same time he wanted to make sure he could personalize it and have it be about their manager and friend
description: Maroon 5 paid tribute to their late manager and friend by dedicating the heartfelt new 'Memories' music video to Jordan Feldstein.
